newsitem.title: USA: Barings ups Venezuela, cuts Colombia, Mexico.
newsitem.headline: Barings ups Venezuela, cuts Colombia, Mexico.

text.p: ING Barings said on Friday it upgraded its rating of Venezuela in its model portfolio of Latin American stocks and downgraded Colombia and Mexico.

In a statement, Tim Love, Barings' head of Latin American research and strategy, said he was changing "both short- and long-term recommendations on Venezuela from underweight to overweight based on oil price and positive fixed-income backdrop."
Love changed his short-term recommendation on Colombia from overweight to neutral until U.S. certification or decertification of Colombia as a partner in fighting drug trafficking in early March.
Colombia "remains overweight in the long term on valuation grounds and as a good contrarian bet," Love wrote.
He altered his recommendation on Mexico to modest underweight from neutral over the long term and remained overweight in the short term.
"Tight monetary policy, lower inflation and less overvalued peso are props to a market benefiting from modest" upgrades of gross domestic product and earnings per share, Love wrote.
For other Latin American countries' asset allocation this year, Love recommended overweight both long- and short-term for Argentina and Brazil and underweight long- and short-term for Chile.
He called for short-term underweight and moved to long-term neutral in Peru, adding, "Overweight commodities and privatization plays."
